item.title: Erdogan’s Party in Turkey Regains Parliamentary Majority
item.description: The results of a snap election represent a stunning electoral comeback, and ensure another period of single party government in Turkey.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan greeted supporters outside a polling station in Istanbul on Sunday.

item.title: A Lonely End for South Koreans Who Cannot Afford to Live, or Die
item.description: As a growing number of South Koreans are dying alone with no relative willing to claim their remains and perform a final ritual, an activist and his organization help to fill the void.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Park Jin-ok paying a silent tribute in front of a refrigerator at a morgue where an unclaimed body was kept.

item.title: Zanzibar Bombings May Be Related to a Disputed Election
item.description: On the island of Zanzibar, a bomb exploded near Stone Town, a popular tourist destination renowned for its labyrinthine streets and sense of history.
item.dc:creator: WILLY LOWRY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Chan Koonchung on Imagining a Non-Communist China
item.description: In Mr. Chan’s alternative history novel, “The Second Year of Jianfeng,” the country “would definitely have been a nicer place,” he said.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chan Koonchung, author of “The Second Year of Jianfeng.”

item.title: Memo From Iraq: In Bid to Counter Iran, Ayatollah in Iraq May End Up Emulating It
item.description: In the face of concerns over the growing power of Iran and its militia proxies, Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani has intervened in Iraqi politics, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Posters featuring the image of Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, spiritual leader of Iraq's Shiite Muslims, on sale in Baghdad last year.

item.title: Erdogan’s Party in Turkey Regains Parliamentary Majority
item.description: The results of a snap election represent a stunning electoral comeback, and ensure another period of single party government in Turkey.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Supporters of Turkey's Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P. celebrated outside the party's headquarters in Ankara on Sunday.

item.title: Russia Mourns as Officials Work to Determine Cause of Jet Crash
item.description: A day of mourning was held Sunday for 224 who died in the Egyptian Sinai crash, while the transportation minister said flight recorders had been found.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Flowers and stuffed animals piled up at a makeshift memorial at Pulkovo airport on Sunday, forming a somber scene as Russians commemorated their dead.

item.title: Plastic Boat Sinks Off Greece, Killing 11 Migrants
item.description: A week of bad weather and drownings in the Aegean Sea continued on Sunday with more tragedy.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Militants Attack Popular Hotel in Somalia
item.description: The Shabab, an Islamist group, claimed responsibility after fighters killed at least 10 people at the Sahafi Hotel in Mogadishu.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED IBRAHIM and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Rescuers carrying a person wounded during an attack on Sunday at the Sahafi hotel in Mogadishu, the Somali capital.

item.title: Guinea President’s Re-election Confirmed Despite Fraud Complaints
item.description: A judicial panel that reviewed claims of fraud in the Oct. 11 election certified that the incumbent, Alpha Condé, had won nearly 58 percent of the vote.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: China, Japan and South Korea Pledge to Expand Trade at Joint Meeting
item.description: The return of trilateral talks among the three powers, last held in 2012, reflects their reliance on one another for badly needed growth.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Al Qaeda Claims Responsibility for Attacks on 2 Publishers in Bangladesh
item.description: The victims’ publishing houses had released work by Avijit Roy, a critic of religious extremism who was killed in a similar attack eight months ago.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: U.S. and Cuba in Trade Talks, for Ballplayers to Be Named Later
item.description: The Obama administration and Major League Baseball have been quietly working to create a system that would end the arduous journey Cuban baseball players have been forced to endure, and open up a huge untapped fan base and a deep well of talent.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: A game between Mayabeque and Granma last year at Nelson Fernández Stadium in San Jose, Cuba.

item.title: ISIS Is Target of Turkish Bombing Raids
item.description: Jets from Turkey targeted the Islamic State in Syria, a government official said on Saturday, a day before Turkish parliamentary elections.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: U.N. Chief Says World’s Failure to Act on Suffering Is a ‘Disgrace’
item.description: Ban Ki-moon, the secretary general of the United Nations, said on Saturday that the world had responded with “disturbing paralysis” to conflicts around the globe and their devastating impact on civilians.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: In One-Child China, Second Children Often Live in Limbo
item.description: People born outside the former “one child” limit are stateless inhabitants of their own country — without the identity documents, rights and services that usually come with citizenship.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A slogan on a wall in the village of Futang reads, “All citizens must observe the law, a single child is glorious.”

item.title: Lights Out in Britain for the Coal Industry
item.description: The once mighty economic enterprise that “put ‘great’ into Great Britain” has succumbed to pressure from cheaper imported coal.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kellingley colliery has been cut to little more than a quarter of its peak work force and is succumbing to pressure from cheaper imported coal.

item.title: Russian Airliner Crashes in Egypt, Killing 224
item.description: The Kogalymavia flight from the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh to St. Petersburg crashed shortly after takeoff, officials said.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: Debris in the Sinai Peninsula of Egypt where a plane bound for St. Petersburg, Russia, crashed. The flight recorder was recovered.

item.title: Officer Randolph Holder Is Buried in His Native Guyana
item.description: Crowds lined the streets of the capital city of Georgetown on Saturday to honor a man who was fatally shot in the line of duty in Manhattan. Dozens of New York police officers were also on hand.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MARKS and BENJAMIN MUELLER

item.title: News Analysis: Discordant Verdicts on U.S. Forces in Syria: Too Much, or Too Little
item.description: Critics in both parties said President Obama’s decision to send a small team of American commandos into Syria reflected a tactical shift rather than a comprehensive strategy.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A victim of an airstrike in Douma, on the outskirts of Damascus, which local activists blamed on pro-government forces.
